t:
There are many intricate ways to love a person.
You can steal them away in the dead of night,
crossing seas and boundaries, igniting a war of many.
To do this properly, you require a city of gold,
a thousand ships, a face that launches them, and one
heart that yearns for another.

                                                                                   cont...
c:
Or you can meet in secret, under the cover of darkness,
exchanging vows and promises, defying the stars themselves.
But for this, you need a moonlit balcony,
two feuding houses, a friar with a plan, a vial of potion,
and a love so deep it ends in tragedy.

Dispensing with secrecy, you may, if the heart allows,
build a monument to them. But then you need
a river of tears, a mausoleum of marble,
not to mention skilled artisans, precious gemstones,
more marbles, a love story etched in stone, and
a symbol of love that stands the test of time.

In an age of steam and steel, you may find
love on a ship bound for destiny. All you then
require is an iceberg in your path, two
lives intertwined, a string quartet playing,
several lifeboats short, a promise and
a love that even death can not part.

These are, as I began, intricate ways
to love a person. Simpler, direct, and much more profound
is to know that you love them in the depths of your heart,
even though they remain untouched by your affection.
And that's enough.



This was pretty much 'Five Ways to Kill a Man' by Edwin Brock.


If you are good with words, you might like this: https://sherlockdoyle.github.io/antonemo/ (link also available in profile)
